subject: Re: [junit] using JUnit with derived classes
msgSnippet: ...  ... I don t like the built-in assumption that tests belong to production code. A test is just another client of the production code, and clients
messageBody:
Curt Sampson wrote:
> On Wed, 12 May 2004, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

<snip />
> However, now that I've played around with Ruby a bit, I am rather
> getting to like the idea of getting the test and production code
> "closer together." I often put my test classes in the same file as the
> production code, which can save a lot of switching back and forth. You
> can even define a but of the production class, a bit of the test class
> with the tests for that method or whatever, a bit more of the production
> class, and so on.

I don't like the built-in assumption that tests belong to production
code. A test is just another client of the production code, and clients
do not belong to providers. The implied dependency is in the wrong
direction and generally that way lie dragons.

> > Why do you want a production class also to be a test? I think it's
> > generally a very bad idea.
>
> I don't see what the problem with it is. It might cause a bit of code
> bloat, but that's often not a problem in many projects.

I disagree with the notion that code bloat is not a common problem.
Refactoring exists in part because of code bloat.

As for the first part, I admit my reaction is mostly irrational, but the
notion that tests are clients of the production code is so ingrained in
my thinking that I'm not easily swayed to think otherwise. It is my turn
to sit back and be the patient observer who isn't quick to adopt a new
idea without sufficient proof that it's worth adopting. (I suppose that
happens to everyone some of the time.)

> > This brings up something I am struggling with: in C#/NUnit, we can
> > declare a test without extending TestCase (even if we frequently extend
> > Assert, anyway). Is there some great benefit to this over the way we do
> > it in JUnit, SUnit, RubyUnit, PyUnit, ...?
>
> You can do the same in Ruby's Test::Unit:
<snip-example />

> One can even keep the "dynamic" feel of this but still have static
> typing by having the compiler do type inference, as done in Haskell and
> ML.

I know it's possible, but I don't know why it's valuable. Can someone
with experience doing both make a comparison? Weblog? Anything?
